headline: New planet that could support human life discovered 'close' to Earth by UK scientists | Science, Climate & Tech News | Sky News
context: UK scientists have discovered a new planet that could potentially support human life and it isn't that far awayâ€¦ relatively speaking.
The temperature on Gliese 12b is around 42C which means it could be liveable. In fact, it is one of the few known planets where humans could theoretically survive.

annotations.paragraph: "It'd be uncomfortable for a human but the way we define 'habitability' is that liquid water could exist on the surface of the planet, which in this case it could," says Larissa Palethorpe from University of Edinburgh.
annotations.reason: Provides a direct quote explaining the criteria for habitability and its relevance to the new planet.

annotations.paragraph: Ms Palethorpe and a team of scientists from around the world used NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, known as TESS, to spot the planet orbiting around its star. It took them less than a year to then calculate its size, temperature and how it moves.
annotations.reason: Describes the method and timeline used to discover and analyze the planet, contributing to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: "Smaller planets are really hard to find," said Ms Palethorpe. "We want to know more about Earth-sized planets so we can understand how many other Earths are out there.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the difficulty of finding similar planets and the significance of the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: "Detecting one so nearby is really exciting because it allows us to do follow up analysis of the atmosphere, so we will be able to learn a lot more about it."
annotations.reason: Highlights the importance of the planet's proximity for further research.

annotations.paragraph: Gliese 12b is relatively close in space terms, at just 40 light years away. However, it'd take our fastest spaceship around 300,000 years to get there currently, according to Ms Palethorpe.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the planet's distance and the current limitations of space travel.
